t: Ezekiel 27
The Sinking of Tyre
The*p word of the Lord*s came to me:
“Now, son of man, lament for Tyre.
Say to Tyre, who is situated at the entrance of the sea, merchant of the peoples to many coasts and islands, ‘This is what the Lord God*s says: Tyre,*pn you declared, “I*ln am perfect in beauty.”
Your*ln realm was in the heart of the sea; your*ln builders perfected your beauty.
They*ln constructed all your planking with*ln pine trees from Senir. They*ln took a cedar from Lebanon to*ln make a mast for you.
They*ln made your oars of oaks from Bashan. They*ln made your deck of cypress wood from*ln the coasts of Cyprus, inlaid*ln with ivory.
Your*ln sail was made of fine*ln embroidered linen from Egypt, and*ln served as your banner. Your*ln awning was of blue and purple fabric from*ln the coasts of Elishah.
The*ln inhabitants of Sidon and Arvad were*ln your rowers. Your*ln wise men were within you, Tyre; they*ln were your captains.
The*ln elders of Gebal and its wise men were*ln within you, repairing your leaks. “‘All*ln the ships of the sea and their sailors came*ln to you to barter for your goods.
Men*ln of Persia, Lud, and Put were*ln in your army, serving as your warriors. They*ln hung shields and helmets in you; they*ln gave you splendor.
Men*ln of Arvad and Helech were*ln stationed on your walls all around, and*ln Gammadites were in your towers. They*ln hung their shields all around your walls; they*ln perfected your beauty.
“‘Tarshish*p was your trading partner because of your abundant wealth of every kind. They exchanged silver, iron, tin, and lead for your merchandise.
Javan, Tubal, and Meshech were your merchants. They exchanged slaves and bronze utensils for your goods.
Those from Beth-togarmah exchanged horses, war horses, and mules for your merchandise.
Men of Dedan were also your merchants; many coasts and islands were your regular markets. They brought back ivory tusks and ebony as your payment.
Aram was your trading partner because of your numerous products. They exchanged turquoise, purple and embroidered cloth, fine linen, coral, and rubies for your merchandise.
Judah and the land of Israel were your merchants. They exchanged wheat from Minnith, meal, honey, oil, and balm, for your goods.
Damascus was also your trading partner because of your numerous products and your abundant wealth of every kind, trading in wine from Helbon and white wool.
Vedan and Javan from Uzal dealt in your merchandise; wrought iron, cassia, and aromatic cane were exchanged for your goods.
Dedan was your merchant in saddlecloths for riding.
Arabia and all the princes of Kedar were your business partners, trading with you in lambs, rams, and goats.
The merchants of Sheba and Raamah traded with you. For your merchandise they exchanged the best of all spices and all kinds of precious stones as well as gold.
Haran, Canneh, Eden, the merchants of Sheba, Asshur, and Chilmad traded with you.
They were your merchants in choice garments, cloaks of blue and embroidered materials, and multicolored carpets, which were bound and secured with cords in your marketplace.
Ships of Tarshish were the carriers for your goods. “‘So*pn you became full and heavily loaded in*ln the heart of the sea.
Your*ln rowers have brought you onto*ln the high seas, but*ln the east wind has wrecked you in*ln the heart of the sea.

Your*ln wealth, merchandise, and goods, your*ln sailors and captains, those*ln who repair your leaks, those*ln who barter for your goods, and*ln all the warriors on board, with*ln all the other people within you, sink*ln into the heart of the sea on*ln the day of your downfall.
“‘The*pn countryside shakes at*ln the sound of your sailors’ cries.
All*ln the oarsmen disembark*ln from their ships. The*ln sailors and all the captains of the sea stand*ln on the shore.
Because*ln of you, they raise their voices and*ln cry out bitterly. They*ln throw dust on their heads; they*ln roll in ashes.
They*ln shave their heads because of you and*ln wrap themselves in sackcloth. They*ln weep over you with*ln deep anguish and bitter mourning.
“‘In*pn their wailing they lament for you, mourning*ln over you: “Who*ln was like Tyre, silenced*ln in the middle of the sea?
When*ln your merchandise was unloaded from the seas, you*ln satisfied many peoples. You*ln enriched the kings of the earth with*ln your abundant wealth and goods.
Now*ln you are wrecked by the sea in*ln the depths of the waters; your*ln goods and the people within you have*ln gone down.
All*ln the inhabitants of the coasts and islands are*ln appalled at you. Their*ln kings shudder with fear; their*ln faces are contorted.
Those*ln who trade among the peoples scoff*ln at you; you*ln have become an object of horror and*ln will never exist again.”’”
